abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Rajasthan District
            Poverty Initiatives Project for India were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately satisfactory; the risk to
            development outcome was moderate; the Bank performance was
            moderately satisfactory; and the Borrower performance was
            also moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            The continuous availability of professionals in key
            financial positions should be agreed during project
            negotiations and it should be a legal covenant in the
            project agreement. A gestation period of one year at the
            outset of the project should be set aside for setting up
            project management infrastructure, training of staff, and
            formation of partnerships with outside stakeholders. It is
            important that the government ensure that staff with a
            procurement background are hired and are responsible for
            contract administration. In addition there should be scope
            for arbitration on non-government organizations (NGO)
            contracts with a third-party, which can also help verify the
            background and short-list potential NGO partners for the
            program. Finally there is a the need to focus on completing
            subprojects on time and ensuring utilization certificates
            are issued in a timely manner. The project left these to the
            end, and this resulted in a major campaign to ensure the
            utilization certificates were issued towards the last six
            months to ensure reimbursement from the Bank. The management
            information systems (MIS) system should have been used to
            track this more effectively. All new livelihood projects are
            building robust MIS systems linked to financial management
            software to track such milestones.
